awd_titl_txt: EAGER: CRYO: Development of materials and techniques to enable sub-Kelvin cooling via adiabatic decompression of para-nematic materials.
awd_abstract_narration:
Part 1: Non-Technical Summary
Researchers at Stanford University develop a new method to cool materials to within a degree of absolute zero without requiring the use of costly liquid helium. Such extreme temperatures are necessary for a variety of modern technologies, including some realizations of quantum computers. This high risk/high reward project, which is jointly supported by the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental and Transport Systems and the Division of Materials Research, investigates an approach that works by alternately squeezing materials and then releasing the strain. While the operating principle is straight forward, the technique requires discovery of appropriate materials with very specific physical properties. The proposed research will identify and characterize such materials to enable a more sustainable approach to ultra-low temperature cooling. 

Part 2: Technical Summary
Researchers at Stanford University investigate a new approach to reaching sub-Kelvin temperatures. The method works by alternately squeezing materials and then releasing the strain, through the process of adiabatic decompression referred to in the award title. For the functional material, a specific class of rare earth containing compounds are considered, for which large temperature changes are possible for modest changes in induced strain, i.e. para-nematic materials. The researchers’ approach to use such materials for cryogenic cooling has several specific advantages over existing technologies: it does not require He-3, it does not require magnetic fields, and it can be rapidly cycled. The project, which is jointly supported by the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental and Transport Systems and the Division of Materials Research, has three main objectives: development of appropriate candidate materials; improvement in low-T characterization of their thermo-elastic properties; and reduction to a working thermodynamic cycle. Activities to be performed include crystal growth and characterization of candidate materials; measurement of low-temperature elastocaloric response over a wide range of strains; improvements in thermometry; and design, construction and testing of a simple working model that would demonstrate such a cooling effect.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
NSF DMR EAGER 2232515

Project Title: EAGER: CRYO: Development of materials and techniques to enable sub-Kelvin cooling via adiabatic decompression of para-nematic materials.

Final project report covering period 09/01/2022 to 12/01/2024

I. R. Fisher

Department of Applied Physics, Stanford University.

03/14/2024

This project resulted in two significant publications on cryogenic cooling via adiabatic decompression.

The first, entitled “Giant elastocaloric effect at low temperatures in TmVO4 and implications for cryogenic cooling”, PNAS 121 (25) e2320052121 (2024) was Published 13 June 2024. The paper is available at https://www.pnas.org/doi/10.1073/pnas.2320052121.

The second, entitled “Giant elastocaloric cooling at cryogenic temperatures in TmVO4 via a load-unload strain technique”, Phys. Rev. Applied 23, 014079 (2025) was published 31 January, 2025. The paper is available at https://journals.aps.org/prapplied/abstract/10.1103/PhysRevApplied.23.014079

To summarize these two papers, we find compelling evidence that adiabatic decompression of para-nematic materials can be used for cryogenic cooling. Our experiments focused on TmVO4 as a test case. The critical temperature of a ferroquadrupolar (nematic) phase transition in this material at 2.15 K limits the ultimate base temperature for cooling using TmVO4. Our results point to the wider class of para-nematic materials as being ideal for cryogenic cooling in the sub-Kelvin regime, requiring materials for which any long-range order occurs substantially below 1K.

In detail, our work has established (1) the entropy landscape of TmVO4 as a function of shear strain and temperature; (2) the divergence of the quadrupole-strain susceptibility of TmVO4 upon cooling; (3) the heating/cooling effects associated with adiabatic compression/decompression of TmVO4; (4) the limiting behavior affecting cooling following adiabatic decompression that is associated with quadrupolar order.

This work involved the development of a novel load/unload technique to measure adiabatic temperature changes upon strain changes using a commercial Razorbill strain cell.

Our work also directly lead to a provisional patent, filed on Dec 10th 2024, entitled “CRYOGENIC ELASTOCALORIC HEAT PUMP AND ASSOCIATED METHODS”. 

Two graduate students and one post-doc were supported, wholly or in part, by this award.

Broader impacts of the work associated with graduate student and post-doc training resulted in the post-doc accepting a faculty position, and the graduate student landing an industry job. More widely, development of a new method for cryogenic cooling has the potential for a transformative change in sub-Kelvin cooling technologies.
